{{Redirect|Gay bash|the [[Drawn Together]] episode|List of Drawn Together episodes#Season 1 (2004){{!}}List of Drawn Together episodes}} {{Globalize/West|date=December 2017}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2017}}
{{Discrimination sidebar}} {{LGBT sidebar}}
'''Gay bashing''' and '''gay bullying''' is [[verbal abuse|verbal]] or [[physical abuse]] against a person who is perceived by the aggressor to be [[gay]], [[lesbian]], [[bisexual]], [[transgender]], including persons who identify as [[heterosexual]].
A "[[Bashing (pejorative)|bashing]]" may be a specific incident, and one could also use the verb ''to bash'' (e.g. "I was gay bashed."). A verbal gay bashing might use sexual slurs, expletives, [[intimidation]], and threatened or actual violence. It also might take place in a political forum and include one or more common [[anti-gay slogan]]s.
Gay bullying involves intentional and unprovoked actions toward the victim, repeated negative actions by one or more people against another person, and an imbalance of physical or psychological power.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=US Dept of Education |title=Bullying Myths and Facts |accessdate=October 2, 2010 |url=http://www2.ed.gov/admins/lead/safety/training/bullying/bullying_pg3.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325204905/http://www2.ed.gov/admins/lead/safety/training/bullying/bullying_pg3.html |archivedate=March 25, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Similar terms such as ''lesbian bullying'', ''[[queer]] bullying'', and ''queer bashing'' may also be formed.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.rutgersuniversitypress.org/violence-against-queer-people/9780813573151|title=Violence against Queer People|last=Meyer|first=Doug|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
== Context == {{Expand section|date=December 2010}}
Gay bashing has occurred worldwide for many decades and continues today.<ref>{{cite web|first=Thomas|last=Rogers|url=http://www.salon.com/2010/12/12/lgbt_bullying_interview/|title=Explaining American schools' gay bullying epidemic|publisher=Salon.com|accessdate=December 12, 2010}}</ref> [[Homophobia in the United States]] was especially serious in the late 1940s and early 1950s, when many gay people were forced out of government by boards set up by Presidents [[Harry S. Truman]] and [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sears|first1=Brad|last2=Hunter|first2=Nan D.|last3=Mallory|first3=Christy|title=Documenting Discrimination on the Basis of Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity in State Employment|date=September 2009|publisher=The Williams Institute on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity Law and Public Policy at UCLA School of Law|location=Los Angeles|page=5–3|url=https://williamsinstitute.law.ucla.edu/wp-content/uploads/5_History.pdf#page=3|quote=From 1947 to 1961, more than 5,000 allegedly homosexual federal civil servants lost their jobs in the purges for no reason other than sexual orientation, and thousands of applicants were also rejected for federal employment for the same reason. During this period, more than 1,000 men and women were fired for suspected homosexuality from the State Department alone—a far greater number than were dismissed for their membership in the Communist party. The Cold War and anti-communist efforts provided the setting in which a sustained attack upon gay men and lesbians took place. The history of this 'Lavender Scare' by the federal government has been extensively documented by historian David Johnson. Johnson has demonstrated that during this era government officials intentionally engaged in campaigns to associate homosexuality with Communism: 'homosexual' and 'pervert' became synonyms for 'Communist' and 'traitor.' LGBT people were treated as a national security threat, demanding the attention of Congress, the courts, statehouses, and the media.}}</ref> As historian [[David K. Johnson]] explains:<ref name="uchicago">{{cite web|url=http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/404811in.html|publisher=University of Chicago Press|title=An interview with David K. Johnson}}</ref>
{{quote|The [[Lavender Scare]] helped fan the flames of the [[Red Scare]]. In popular discourse, [[communist]]s and homosexuals were often conflated. Both groups were perceived as hidden [[subculture]]s with their own meeting places, literature, cultural codes, and bonds of loyalty. Both groups were thought to recruit to their ranks the psychologically weak or disturbed. And both groups were considered immoral and godless. Many people believed that the two groups were working together to undermine the government.}}
Johnson concludes that Senator [[Joe McCarthy]], notorious for his attacks on alleged communists in government, was often pressured by his allies to denounce homosexuals in government, but he resisted and did not do so.<ref name="uchicago" /> Using rumors collected by [[Drew Pearson (journalist)|Drew Pearson]], one [[Nevada]] publisher wrote in 1952 that both McCarthy and his chief counsel, [[Roy Cohn]], were homosexuals.<ref group="note">After McCarthy called him an ex-Communist, [[Hank Greenspun]] wrote: "It is common talk among homosexuals in [[Milwaukee]] who rendezvous in the White Horse Inn that Senator Joe McCarthy has often engaged in homosexual activities." [[Las Vegas Sun]], October 25, 1952. McCarthy later explained he meant to call Greenspun an ex-convict (which was true), rather than an ex-Communist (which was false).</ref> ''[[Washington Post]]'' editor [[Benjamin C. Bradlee]] said, "There was a lot of time spent investigating" these allegations, "although no one came close to proving it." No reputable McCarthy biographer has accepted it as probable.<ref group="note">The allegations are specifically rejected in Richard Rovere, ''Senator Joe McCarthy'' (1969), p. 68; see also Robert D. Dean, ''Imperial Brotherhood: Gender and the Making of Cold War Foreign Policy'' (2001) p. 149 (includes Bradlee quote); Kyle A. Cuordileone, ''Manhood and American Political Culture in the Cold War'' (2003), p. 94; Thomas Patrick Doherty, ''Cold War, Cool Medium: Television, McCarthyism, and American Culture,'' (2003), p. 228. Geoff Schumacher, ''Sun, Sin & Suburbia: An Essential History of Modern Las Vegas'' (2004), p. 144, concludes, "Greenspun descended into mud-spewing rhetoric that would make the [[National Enquirer]] blanch." Knowing that McCarthy would not dare enter Nevada, where he would be served with a lawsuit for defaming Greenspun, Greenspun punished McCarthy with his own weapon of anonymous, scandalous accusations.</ref>
=== Queer bullying ===
[[Egale Canada]] conducted a survey of more than 3700 high school students in Canada between December 2007 and June 2009. The final report of the survey, "Every Class in Every School",<ref>[http://egale.ca/youth-and-safer-schools/every-class/ Every Class in Every School], Final Report on the First National Climate Survey on Homophobia, Biphobia, and Transphobia in Canadian Schools, Egale Canada</ref> published in 2011, found that 70% of all students participating heard "that's so gay" daily at school, and 48% of respondents heard "faggot", "lezbo" and "dyke" daily. 58% or about 1400 of the 2400 heterosexual students participating in EGALE's survey found homophobic comments upsetting. Further, EGALE found that students not directly affected by [[homophobia]], [[biphobia]] or [[transphobia]] were less aware of it. This finding relates to research done in the area of [[Empathy gap|empathy gaps for social pain]] which suggests that those not directly experiencing social pain (in this case, bullying) consistently underestimate its effects and thus may not adequately respond to the needs of one experiencing social pain.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Nordgren | first1 = L. F. | last2 = Banas | first2 = K. | last3 = MacDonald | first3 = G. | year = 2011 | title = Empathy Gaps for Social Pain: Why People Underestimate the Pain of Social Suffering | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 100 | issue = 1| pages = 120–128 | doi=10.1037/a0020938 | pmid=21219077}}</ref>
EGALE, along with previous research<ref name="Crozier">{{cite journal | last1 = Crozier | first1 = W. R. | last2 = Skliopidou | first2 = E. | year = 2002 | title = Adult Recollections of Name-calling at School | url = | journal = Educational Psychology | volume = 22 | issue = 1| pages = 113–124 | doi=10.1080/01443410120101288}}</ref><ref name="Phoenix">{{cite journal | last1 = Phoenix | first1 = A. | last2 = Frosh | first2 = S. | last3 = Pattman | first3 = R. | year = 2003 | title = Producing Contradictory Masculine Subject Positions: Narratives of Threat, Homophobia and Bullying in 11-14 Year Old Boys | url = | journal = Journal of Social Issues | volume = 59 | issue = 1| pages = 179–195 | doi=10.1111/1540-4560.t01-1-00011}}</ref><ref name="Smith">{{cite journal | last1 = Smith | first1 = G. W. | year = 1998 | title = The Ideology of "Fag": The School Experience of Gay Students | url = | journal = The Sociological Quarterly | volume = 39 | issue = 2| pages = 309–335 | doi=10.1111/j.1533-8525.1998.tb00506.x}}</ref><ref name="Swearer">{{cite journal | last1 = Swearer | first1 = S. M. | last2 = Turner | first2 = R. K. | last3 = Givens | first3 = J. E. | last4 = Pollack | first4 = W. S. | year = 2008 | title = You're So Gay!": Do Different Forms of Bullying Matter for Adolescent Males?. | url = | journal = School Psychology Review | volume = 37 | issue = 2| pages = 160–173 }}</ref> has found teachers and school administration may be complicit in queer bullying through their silence and/or inaction.
Graffiti found on school grounds and property, and its "relative permanence",<ref name="Smith" /> is another form of queer bullying.
Some researchers suggest including youth questioning their sexuality in any research on queer bullying because they may be as susceptible to its effects<ref name="Swearer" /><ref name="R&J">{{cite journal | last1 = Russell | first1 = S. T. | last2 = Joyner | first2 = K. | year = 2001 | title = Adolescent Sexual Orientation and Suicide Risk: Evidence From a National Study | journal = American Journal of Public Health | volume = 91 | issue = 8| pages = 1276–1281 | doi=10.2105/ajph.91.8.1276 | pmid=11499118 | pmc=1446760}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Williams | first1 = T. | last2 = Connolly | first2 = J. | last3 = Pepler | first3 = D. | last4 = Craig | first4 = W. | year = 2005 | title = Peer Victimization, Social Support, and Psychosocial Adjustment of Sexual Minority Adolescents | url = http://bullylab.com/Portals/0/Peer%20Victimization%2C%20Social%20Support%2C%20and%20Psychosocial%20adjustment%20of%20sexual%20minority%20adolescents.pdf| journal = Journal of Youth and Adolescence | volume = 34 | issue = 5| pages = 471–482 | doi=10.1007/s10964-005-7264-x| citeseerx = 10.1.1.459.218 }}</ref> as queer students.
A research study of 78 eleven to fourteen-year-old boys conducted in twelve schools in London, England between 1998 and 1999<ref name="Phoenix" /> revealed that respondents who used the word "gay" to label another boy in a derogatory manner intended the word as "just a joke", "just a cuss" and not as a statement of one's perceived [[sexual orientation]].<ref name="Smith" /><ref>Pascoe, C. J. (2007). Dude You're a Fag, Masculinity and Sexuality in High School. Berkeley & Los Angeles, CA: University of California Press</ref> American sociologist [[Michael Kimmel]] and American psychologist [[Gregory Herek]] write that [[masculinity]] is a renunciation of the feminine and that males shore up their sense of their masculinity by denigrating the feminine and ultimately the homosexual.<ref>Kimmel, M. (2010). Masculinity as Homophobia, Fear, Shame and Silence in the Construction of Gender Identity. In M. S. Kimmel & A. L. Ferber (Eds.), Privilege, A Reader (pp.107-131). Boulder: Westview Press</ref><ref name="Herek">{{cite journal | last1 = Herek | first1 = G. M. | year = 1986 | title = On Heterosexual Masculinity, Some Psychical Consequences of the Social Construction of Gender and Sexuality | url = | journal = American Behavioral Scientist | volume = 29 | issue = 5| pages = 563–577 | doi=10.1177/000276486029005005}}</ref> Building on the notion of masculinity defining itself by what it is not, some researchers suggest that in fact the renunciation of the feminine may be [[misogyny]].<ref name="Phoenix" /><ref name="Smith" /> These intertwining issues were examined in 2007, when American sociologist [[CJ Pascoe]] described what she calls the "[[Faggot (slang)|fag discourse]]" at an American high school in her book, ''[[Dude, You're a Fag]]''.
Gay and lesbian youth are more likely to report bullying.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Berlan, ED |author2=Corliss, HL |author3=Field, AE |title= Sexual Orientation and Bullying Among Adolescents in the Growing Up Today Study |journal= Journal of Adolescent Health |date=April 2010 |volume=46 |pages=366–71 | doi = 10.1016/j.jadohealth.2009.10.015 |pmid=20307826 |pmc=2844864 |issue=4|display-authors=etal}}</ref> In one study, boys who were bullied with taunts of being gay suffered more bullying and more negative effects compared with boys who were bullied with other categories of taunting.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Swearer, SM |author2=Turner, RT |author3=Givens, JE |title="You're so gay!": Do different forms of bullying matter for adolescent males? |journal= School Psychology Review |year=2008 |volume=37}}</ref>
== Causes of queer bullying ==
Gay and lesbian youth can develop severe forms of depression and anxiety as they grow up. In fact, 71.4% of LGBT folk experience major depression disorder (MDD).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sweet|first1=Matt|title=Depression and Anxiety in LGBT People: What You Need to Know|url=http://www.mattsweet.com/lgbt-anxiety-depression-guide.pdf|accessdate=July 18, 2017}}</ref> For LGBT individuals, MDD can be caused by any of the following: self-esteem, pressure to conform, minority stress, coming out, family rejection, parenting, relationship formation, and violence.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sweet|first1=Matt|title=Depression and Anxiety in the LGBT People: What You Need to Know|url=http://www.mattsweet.com/lgbt-anxiety-depression-guide.pdf}}</ref> Self-esteem and pressure to conform go hand in hand. When an LGBT individual is told what to look like and who to love, it puts a toll on their self-esteem. When people make comments about who they are, what they look like, who they love, etc. it begins to make them feel insecure. It makes them feel as though they aren't good enough the way they are. "Coming-out" is a terms that is used to describe when an LGBT individual makes it known that they are gay, lesbian, etc. Coming out is usually the first factor that will affect a person involved in the LGBT community because when they first discover who they really are, their instinct is to confide in their parents to help them through it (Markheim, Personal Interview). When they experience family rejection after coming out, they automatically feel unwanted and unloved. This can set them into a downward spiral of depression. Parenting and relationship formation are very closely related because usually, people feel more comfortable parenting with their significant other rather than alone, especially if they are involved in the LGBT community. Just recently, in March 2016, is became legal for LGBT parents to adopt in all 50 states.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Reilly|first1=Mollie|title=Same-Sex Couples Can Now Adopt Children in All 50 States|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/mississippi-same-sex-adoption_us_56fdb1a3e4b083f5c607567f|newspaper=Huffington Post|accessdate=July 18, 2017|date=April 2016}}</ref> Not being able to conceive their own child can already cause depression, but when they were denied the right to adopt, it caused even more pain. Minority stress is not the biggest of all the factors, but it doesn't make anybody feel better. Minority stress is defined as a stress experienced by LGBT individuals due to their sexual orientation/gender identity.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Meyer|first1=Ilan|title=Minority Stress and Mental Health in Gay Men|journal=Journal of Health and Social Behavior|date=March 1995|volume= 36|issue= 1|page=38 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/15461517|accessdate=July 24, 2017|doi=10.2307/2137286|jstor=2137286}}</ref> Violence can slip anybody into a depressed state whether the violence is a type of physical abuse, mental abuse, or verbal abuse. A person can be harassed to the point where their depression becomes to much and they no longer experience any happiness. These factors all work together and make it extremely hard to avoid MDD.
== Effects of queer bullying ==
Queer bullying may make some victims feel sad and unsafe in the world.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Glew | first1 = G. M. | last2 = Fan | first2 = M. | last3 = Katon | first3 = W. | last4 = Rivara | first4 = F. P. | last5 = Kernic | first5 = M. A. | year = 2005 | title = Bullying, Psychosocial Adjustment, and Academic Performance in Elementary School | url = | journal = Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine | volume = 159 | issue = 11| pages = 1026–1031 | doi=10.1001/archpedi.159.11.1026| pmid = 16275791 }}</ref><ref name="Roth">{{cite journal | last1 = Roth | first1 = D. A. | last2 = Coles | first2 = M. E. | last3 = Heimberg | first3 = R. G. | year = 2002 | title = The relationship between memories for childhood teasing and anxiety and depression in adulthood | url = | journal = Journal of Anxiety Disorders | volume = 16 | issue = 2| pages = 149–164 | doi=10.1016/s0887-6185(01)00096-2}}</ref> Bullying will affect a student's experience of school. Some victims might feel paralyzed and withdraw socially as a coping mechanism.<ref name="Crozier" /> Other victims of queer bullying may begin to live the effects of [[learned helplessness]].<ref name="Roth" /> Queer or [[Questioning (sexuality and gender)|questioning]] students may try to pass as heterosexual in order to avoid queer bullying. [[Passing (sexual orientation)|Passing]] isolates the student from other queer or questioning students, potential [[Straight ally|allies]], and support.<ref name="Smith" /> Adults who try to pass also may feel the effects emotionally and psychologically, of this effort to conceal their true identities.<ref name="Herek" /> Queer and questioning youth who experience bullying have a higher incidence of substance abuse and STI and HIV infection,<ref name="R&J" /><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Russell | first1 = S. T. | last2 = Ryan | first2 = C. | last3 = Toomey | first3 = R. B. | last4 = Diaz | first4 = R. M. | last5 = Sanchez | first5 = J. | year = 2011 | title = Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Adolescent School Victimization: Implications for Young Adult Health and Adjustment | url = | journal = Journal of School Health | volume = 81 | issue = 5| pages = 223–230 | doi=10.1111/j.1746-1561.2011.00583.x| pmid = 21517860 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Rivers | first1 = I | year = 2004 | title = Recollections of Bullying at School and Their Long-Term Implications for Lesbians, Gay Men and Bisexuals | url = | journal = Crisis | volume = 25 | issue = 4| pages = 169–175 | doi=10.1027/0227-5910.25.4.169| pmid = 15580852 }}</ref> which may carry through to adulthood. Queer bullying may also be seen as a manifestation of what American academic [[Ilan Meyer]] calls ''[[minority stress]]'',<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Meyer | first1 = I. H. | year = 1995 | title = Minority Stress and Mental Health in Gay Men | url = | journal = Journal of Health and Social Behavior | volume = 36 | issue = 1| pages = 38–56 | doi=10.2307/2137286| pmid = 7738327 | jstor = 2137286 }}</ref> which may affect sexual and ethno-racial minorities attempting to exist within a challenging broader society.
== Explicit and implicit homophobic and transphobic discriminatory behavior in educational settings ==
Homophobic and transphobic violence in educational settings can be categorized as explicit and implicit. Explicit homophobic and transphobic violence consists of overt acts that make subjects feel uncomfortable, hurt, humiliated or intimidated. Peers and educational staff are unlikely to intervene when witnessing these incidents. This contributes to normalizing such acts that become accepted as either a routine disciplinary measure or a means to resolve conflicts among students. Homophobic and transphobic violence – as with all school-related gender-based violence – is acutely underreported due to subjects’ fear of retribution, combined with inadequate or non-existent reporting, support and redress systems.<ref>GMR, UNESCO, and UNGEI, ‘School-related gender-based violence is preventing the achievement of quality education for all: Policy Paper 17 at 59th session of the Commission on the Status of Women in New York City’, 59th session of the Commission on the Status of Women in New York City. UNESCO, p. 16, 2015.</ref><ref>Plan International, ‘A Girl’s Right to Learn Without Fear: Working to end gender-based violence at school’, Plan Limited, Surrey, 2013.</ref><ref>S. Bloom, J. Levy, N. Karim, L. Stefanik, M. Kincaid, D. Bartel, and K. Grimes, ‘Guidance for Gender Based Violence (GBV) Monitoring and Mitigation within Non-GBV Focused Sectoral Programming’, CARE USA, 2014.</ref><ref>Plan UK, ‘Ending school-related gender-based violence: Brie ng paper’, London, 2013.</ref> The absence of effective policies, protection or remedies contributes to a vicious cycle where incidents become increasingly normal.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002447/244756e.pdf|title=Out in the Open: Education sector responses to violence based on sexual orientation and gender identity/expression|last=UNESCO|publisher=Paris, UNESCO|year=2016|isbn=978-92-3-100150-5|location=|pages=26}}</ref>
Implicit homophobic and transphobic violence, sometimes called ‘symbolic violence’ or ‘institutional’ violence, is subtler than explicit violence. It consists of pervasive representations or attitudes that sometimes feel harmless or natural to the school community, but that allow or encourage homophobia and transphobia, including perpetuating harmful stereotypes. Policies and guidelines can reinforce or embed these representations or attitudes, whether in an individual institution or across an entire education sector. This way, they can become part of everyday practices and rules guiding school behaviour.<ref>ICGBV, ‘Addressing School Related Gender Based Violence: Learning from Practice: Learning Brief No. 10’, Irish Consortium on Gender Based Violence, Dublin, 2013.</ref><ref>F. Leach, M. Dunne, and F. Salvi, ‘School-Related Gender based Violence: A global review of current issues and approaches in policy, programming and implementation responses to School-Related Gender-Based Violence (SRGBV) for the Education Sector’, UNESCO, 2014.</ref><ref name=":0" /> Examples of implicit homophobic and transphobic violence include:
* Asserting that some subjects are better suited to students based on their sexual orientation or gender identity/expression (for example, science for heterosexual male students and drama for gay male students). * Suggesting that it is normal for heterosexual students to have greater agency or influence (for example, with the opinions of LGBTI students treated as marginal and unimportant). * Reinforcing stereotypes related to sexual orientation or gender identity/expression in curriculum materials or teacher training, such as through images and discourse (for example, that refer to heterosexuality as ‘normal’). * Reinforcing stereotypes related to sexual orientation or gender identity/expression in educational policies, rules and regulations (for example, by not even acknowledging that LGBTI students are part of the school community and by not specifying them in relevant policies).<ref name=":0" />
== Statistics and examples ==
Teens face harassment, threats, and violence. A 1998 study in the US by [[Mental Health America]] found that students heard anti-gay slurs such as "homo", "faggot" and "sissy" about 26 times a day on average, or once every 14 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mental Health American, Bullying and Gay Youth |url=http://www.nmha.org/go/information/get-info/children-s-mental-health/bullying-and-gay-youth |publisher=National Mental Health Association |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414144851/http://www.nmha.org/go/information/get-info/children-s-mental-health/bullying-and-gay-youth |archivedate=April 14, 2012}}</ref> In a study conducted by the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, a union for UK professionals, the word "gay" was reported to be the most popular term of abuse heard by teachers on a regular basis.<ref>{{Cite news|title=How 'gay' Became Children's Insult of Choice|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7289390.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=2008-03-18}}</ref>
About two-thirds of gay and lesbian students in [[Great Britain|British]] schools have suffered from gay bullying in 2007, according to a study done by the [[Schools Education Unit]] for [[LGBT|LGB]] activist group [[Stonewall (charity)|Stonewall]]. Almost all that had been bullied had experienced verbal attacks, 41 percent had been physically attacked, and 17 percent had received death threats. It also showed that over 50% of teachers did not respond to homophobic language which they had explicitly heard in the classroom, and only 25% of schools had told their students that homophobic bullying was wrong, showing "a shocking picture of the extent of homophobic bullying undertaken by fellow pupils and, alarmingly, school staff",<ref>{{Cite news|publisher=BBC News|title=Gay Bullying in Schools Common|date=June 26, 2007 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6239098.stm}}</ref> with further studies conducted by the same charity in 2012 stated that 90% of teachers had had no training on the prevention of homophobic bullying. However, Ofsted's new 2012 framework did ask schools what they would be doing in order to combat the issue.<ref name=Stonewall1>{{cite web|title=Homophobic bullying|url=http://www.stonewall.org.uk/at_school/education_for_all/secondary_schools/homophobic_bullying/default.asp|website=stonewall.org.uk|publisher=Stonewall |accessdate=December 25, 2014}}</ref>
The rate of suicide is higher among LGBT people. According to a 1979 Jay and Young study, 40 percent of gay men and 39 percent of gay women in the US had attempted or seriously thought about suicide.<ref name="ncmh">{{cite web|title=Gay Male and Lesbian Youth Suicide |year=1989 |url=http://www.ncmhjj.com/resource_kit/pdfs/Special%20Issues/References/GayMaleLesSuic.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714161413/http://www.ncmhjj.com/resource_kit/pdfs/Special%20Issues/References/GayMaleLesSuic.pdf |archivedate=July 14, 2011}}</ref> In the same study conducted by the Schools Education Unit for LGB activist group Stonewall, an online survey reported that 71 percent of the girl participants who identified as LGBTQ, and 57 percent of the boy participants who identified as LGBTQ had seriously considered suicide.<ref>{{cite web|title=The School Report|url=https://www.stonewall.org.uk/sites/default/files/The_School_Report__2012_.pdf|publisher=Stonewall}}</ref> In 1985, F. Paris estimated that suicides by gay youth may comprise up to 30 percent of all youth suicides in the US. This contributes to suicide being the third leading cause for death among youth aged 10–24, reported by the CDC.<ref>{{cite web|title=Suicide Prevention|url=https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/suicide/youth_suicide.html|publisher=Center for Disease Control and Prevention|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170504155435/https://www.cdc.gov/ViolencePrevention/suicide/youth_suicide.html|archivedate=May 4, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The [[American Foundation for Suicide Prevention]] has found that gay, lesbian and bisexual youth attempt suicide at a rate three to six times that of similar-age heterosexual youth.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[American Foundation for Suicide Prevention]] |accessdate=October 2, 2010 |url=http://www.afsp.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.viewPage&page_ID=CF7F9E5B-BF4B-52F3-4D4079E9991163DC |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206160614/http://www.afsp.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.viewPage&page_id=CF7F9E5B-BF4B-52F3-4D4079E9991163DC |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 6, 2010 |title=Statistics}}</ref> The Schools Education Unit also reports that in the same online survey, 25 percent of the people who identified as LGBTQ, have attempted to commit suicide.<ref>{{cite web|title=The School Report|url=https://www.stonewall.org.uk/sites/default/files/The_School_Report__2012_.pdf |publisher=Stonewall}}</ref>
=== Cases ===
* In 1996, Jamie Nabozny won a landmark lawsuit (''[[Nabozny v. Podlesny]]'') against officials at his former public high school in [[Ashland, Wisconsin]] over their refusal to intervene in the "relentless antigay verbal and physical abuse by fellow students" to which he had been subjected and which had resulted in his hospitalization.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[Lambda Legal]]|url=http://www.lambdalegal.org/in-court/cases/nabozny-v-podlesny.html|title=Nabozny v. Podlesny|accessdate=December 12, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120725165752/http://www.lambdalegal.org/in-court/cases/nabozny-v-podlesny?qt-related_conent_for_cases=2#qt-related_conent_for_cases|archivedate=July 25, 2012}}</ref> * [[Matthew Shepard]] was an American college student at the University of Wyoming who was both tortured and murdered in Laramie, Wyoming in October 1998, allegedly due to his sexual orientation. His death ultimately led to anti-bullying legislation such as the [[Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.matthewshepard.org/our-story|title=About Us - Matthew Shepard Foundation|publisher=}}</ref> * High school student [[Henkle v. Gregory|Derek Henkle]] faced inaction from school officials when repeatedly harassed by his peers in [[Reno]], [[Nevada]]. His lawsuit against the school district and several administrators ended in a 2002 settlement in which the district agreed to create a series of policies to protect gay and lesbian students and to pay Henkle $451,000.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Merjian|first=Armen H.|title=''Henkle v. Gregory'': A Landmark Struggle against Student Gay Bashing|journal=Cardozo Journal of Law & Gender|date=Fall 2009|volume=16|issue=1|pages=41–64|url=http://www.cardozolawandgender.com/uploads/2/7/7/6/2776881/16-1_merjian.pdf|accessdate=September 4, 2012}}</ref> * [[Damilola Taylor]] was attacked by a local gang of youths on November 27, 2000 in [[Peckham]], [[South London]]; he bled to death after being stabbed with a broken bottle in the thigh, which severed the femoral artery. The BBC, ''Telegraph'', ''Guardian'' and ''Independent'' newspapers reported at the time that during the weeks between arriving in the UK from [[Nigeria]] and the attack he had been subjected to bullying and beating, which included homophobic remarks by a group of boys at his school. "The bullies told him that he was gay."<ref name="BBCDAM">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/1048449.stm|title=Damilola's grieving father speaks out|publisher=BBC News|date=November 30, 2000}}</ref> He "may not have understood why he was being bullied at school, or why some other children taunted him about being 'gay' – the word meant nothing to him."<ref name="GUADAM" /> He had to ask his mother what 'gay' meant, she said "Boys were swearing at him, saying lots of horrible words. They were calling him names."<ref name="GUADAM">{{Cite news|last=Hopkins|first=Nick|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/nov/29/ukcrime.nickhopkins|title=Death of a schoolboy|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 29, 2000}}</ref> His mother had spoken about this bullying, but the teachers failed to take it seriously. "She said pupils had accused her son of being gay and had beaten him last Friday."<ref name="INDAM">{{Cite news|last=Bennetto|first=Jason|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/his-mother-told-teachers-he-was-being-bullied-now-she-must-bury-him-622144.html|title=His mother told teachers he was being bullied. Now she must bury him| newspaper=Independent|date=November 29, 2000}}</ref> One month after the murder, his father said, "I spoke to him and he was crying that he was being bullied and being called names. He was being called 'gay'."<ref name="TELDAM">{{Cite news|last=Steele|first=John|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1377304/Damilolas-father-attacks-loss-of-values.html|title=Damilola's father attacks loss of values|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=June 19, 2001}}</ref> In the ''[[New Statesman]]'' two years later, when there had still been no convictions for the crime, [[Peter Tatchell]], gay human rights campaigner, said, "In the days leading up to his murder in south London in November 2000, he was subjected to vicious homophobic abuse and assaults,"<ref name="NSDAM">{{Cite journal|last=Tatchell|first=Peter|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/200301130014|title=A victim of homophobia?|journal=New Statesman|date=January 13, 2003}}</ref> and asked why the authorities had ignored this before and after his death. * In 2009, Carl Joseph Walker Hoover, an 11-year-old boy in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]], hanged himself with an electrical cord. His mother said his classmates at his middle school had bullied and called him "gay" on a daily basis.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=WCVB TV, Boston|title=Hoover|accessdate=October 20, 2010|url=http://www.thebostonchannel.com/r/19137836/detail.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101005204442/http://www.thebostonchannel.com/r/19137836/detail.html|archivedate=October 5, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * In 2010, a gay man from [[Cameroon]] was granted asylum in the [[United Kingdom]] after reporting that he had been attacked by an angry mob in Cameroon after they saw him kissing his male partner. The Communications Minister of Cameroon, Issa Tchiroma, denied the allegation of persecution of homosexuals.<ref>{{Cite news|publisher=BBC News|title=Cameroon Denies Homosexuals Face Persecution|date=July 8, 2010|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10550576}}</ref> * [[Suicide of Tyler Clementi|Tyler Clementi]] committed suicide on September 22, 2010, after his roommate at [[Rutgers University]] secretly recorded his sexual encounter with another man.<ref name="IanParker">{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2012/02/06/120206fa_fact_parker?currentPage=all|last=Parker|first=Ian|title=The Story of a Suicide|newspaper=The New Yorker|date=February 6, 2012|accessdate=February 5, 2012}}</ref> * A 32-year-old man in Paisley, [[Scotland]] was bullied and harassed by his employer, a [[Glasgow]] publishing firm, before he was fired. He later sued the company and won a £120,000 award.<ref>{{Cite news|publisher=BBC News|title=Harassed gay man's £120,000 award|date=October 2, 2010|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/glasgow_and_west/6353609.stm}}</ref> * On October 14, 2011, Canadian teenager Jamie Hubley, the son of [[Ottawa]] city councillor [[Allan Hubley]], committed suicide after having [[blog]]ged for a month about the anti-gay bullying he was facing at school.<ref name="lonely">[https://web.archive.org/web/20111104203000/http://www.ottawacitizen.com/sports/year+Jamie+Hubley+documented+heartbreaking+need+acceptance/5559352/story.html "15-year-old Jamie Hubley's lonely cry for acceptance"]. ''[[Ottawa Citizen]]'', October 17, 2011.</ref> The bullying had begun as early as Grade 7, with students on Jamie's bus attempting to stuff [[Battery (electricity)|batteries]] in his mouth because he preferred [[figure skating]] over [[ice hockey|hockey]].<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/article/1072227--mallick-meet-the-boy-the-bullies-broke?bn=1 "Mallick: Meet the boy the bullies broke"]. ''[[Toronto Star]]'', October 18, 2011.</ref> * Phillip Parker, a 14-year-old openly gay student in [[Gordonsville, Tennessee]], was found dead on January 20, 2012. He committed suicide because of gay bullying. His father, who is also named Phillip, says that "That's my son. I love him. I miss him. He shouldn't have had to kill himself to be brought to life." Along the body was a letter, which was written: "Please help me mom".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/01/23/phillip-parker-gay-tennessee-teen-suicide_n_1223688.html|title=Phillip Parker, Gay Tennessee Teen, Commits Suicide After Enduring Bullying (VIDEO) |date=January 23, 2012 |accessdate=November 16, 2012 |publisher=Huffigton Post|newspaper=Huffington Post }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/phillip-parker-suicide-bullied-teens-final-words-were-please-help-me-mom-399418|title=Phillip Parker Suicide: Bullied Teen's Final Words Were 'Please Help Me Mom'|date=January 23, 2012 |accessdate=November 16, 2012 |publisher=International Business Times}}</ref> * [[Kenneth Weishuhn]], a 14-year-old freshman from [[South O'Brien High School]] in [[Iowa]], hanged himself in his family's garage after intense anti-gay bullying, cyberbullying and death threats in 2012. His suicide was covered nationally and raised questions about what culpability bullies have in suicides.<ref name=Weishuhn1>{{Cite news|title=Kenneth Weishuhn, Gay Iowa Teen, Commits Suicide After Allegedly Receiving Death Threats|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/17/kenneth-weishuhn-gay-iowa-teen-suicide_n_1431442.html|newspaper=Huffington Post|accessdate=March 21, 2014|date=2012-04-17}}</ref><ref name=EvanQueerty1>{{cite web|last=Mulvihill|first=Evan|title=Heartbreaking Details Emerge In Suicide Of Out Iowa Teen Kenneth Weishuhn|url=http://www.queerty.com/heartbreaking-details-emerge-in-suicide-of-just-out-h-s-freshman-kenneth-weishuhn-20120418/|publisher=Queerty|accessdate=March 21, 2014|date=2012-04-18}}</ref> * [[Jadin Bell]], a 15-year-old youth in [[La Grande]], [[Oregon]], tried to commit suicide by hanging after intense anti-gay bullying at his high school in 2013. After life support was removed, Bell died at the [[OHSU]] hospital. His father Joe Bell started a walk across America to raise awareness about gay bullying, but was hit and killed by a truck halfway through his journey.<ref name=HuffBell1>{{Cite news|last=Nichols|first=James|title=Jadin Bell's Father, Joe Bell, Killed While Walking Cross Country For Tribute To Dead Gay Teen|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/10/joe-bell-dead_n_4079989.html|newspaper=Huffington Post|accessdate=March 20, 2014|date=2013-10-10}}</ref><ref name=JadinBell1>{{cite news|title=Jadin Bell's father Joe Bell of La Grande killed by truck while walking in memory of son|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/pacific-northwest-news/index.ssf/2013/10/jadin_bells_father_joe_bell_of.html|accessdate=March 20, 2014|newspaper=Oregon Live|date=October 10, 2013}}</ref>
== Legislation ==
[[File:School bullying laws in the United States.svg|thumb|300px|Some U.S. states have implemented laws to address school bullying.
{{legend|#800080|Law that prohibits discrimination against students based on sexual orientation and gender identity}}
{{legend|#0066ff|Law that prohibits discrimination against students based on sexual orientation only}}
{{legend|#14a800|Law that prohibits bullying of students based on sexual orientation and gender identity}}
{{legend|#ba75ff|School regulation or ethical code for teachers that address discrimination and/or bullying of students based on sexual orientation and gender identity}}
{{legend|#00ffff|School regulation or ethical code for teachers that address discrimination and/or bullying of students based on sexual orientation only}}
{{legend|#d40000|Law that forbids school-based instruction of LGBT issues in a positive manner}}
{{legend|#7f7f7f|Law that prohibits bullying in school but lists no categories of protection}}
{{legend|#cccccc|No statewide law that specifically prohibits bullying in schools}}]]
{{Expand section|date=December 2010}}
The state of [[Illinois]] passed a law (SB3266) in June 2010 that prohibits gay bullying and other forms of bullying in schools.<ref>{{cite web |title=SB3266 Text |url=http://www.ilga.gov/legislation/fulltext.asp?DocName=&SessionId=76&GA=96&DocTypeId=SB&DocNum=3266&GAID=10&LegID=51081&SpecSess=&Session= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110311201259/http://www.ilga.gov/legislation/fulltext.asp?DocName=&SessionId=76&GA=96&DocTypeId=SB&DocNum=3266&GAID=10&LegID=51081&SpecSess=&Session= |archivedate=March 11, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In the [[Philippines]], legislators implemented Republic Act No. 10627, otherwise known as the Anti-Bullying Act of 2013, in schools. According to the said law, gender-based bullying is defined as ˮany act that humiliates or excludes a person on the basis of perceived or actual sexual orientation and gender identity (SOGI)ˮ.<ref>{{cite web|title=Implementing Rules and Regulations of Republic Act No. 10627|url=http://www.gov.ph/2013/12/13/implementing-rules-and-regulations-of-republic-act-no-10627/|website=Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines|publisher=Government of the Philippines|accessdate=November 10, 2014}}</ref>
== Support ==
In response to growing awareness of gay bashing and bullying, a number of support groups have been founded to help LGBT people cope with their abuse.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} In Europe [[Stonewall (charity)|Stonewall UK]],<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Uk gay news|title=Stonewall, Mayor of London Launch Anti-Homophobic Bullying DVD|accessdate=August 21, 2011|url=http://www.ukgaynews.org.uk/archive/2006july/0401.htm|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328181745/http://www.ukgaynews.org.uk/archive/2006july/0401.htm|archivedate=March 28, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and Anti-Bullying Network<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.antibullying.net/homophobicinfo3.htm|title=Information for Schools on Homophobic Bullying|website=www.antibullying.net}}</ref> are active in the [[United Kingdom|UK]], while [[Russia]] has the [[Russian LGBT network]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Ilga |title=The Russian LGBT Network |accessdate=August 21, 2011 |url=http://ilga-europe.org/home/how_we_work/developing/projects/russian_project/the_russian_lgbt_network |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320021122/http://ilga-europe.org/home/how_we_work/developing/projects/russian_project/the_russian_lgbt_network |archivedate=March 20, 2012}}</ref>
Notable in the [[United States]] is the [[It Gets Better Project]], for which celebrities and ordinary LGBT people make [[YouTube]] videos and share messages of hope for gay teens.<ref name="CNET">{{cite web|publisher=CNET|title=CBS employees join the It Gets Better Project|accessdate=August 21, 2011|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1023_3-20072421-93/cbs-employees-join-the-it-gets-better-project/}}</ref><ref name="MTV">{{cite web|publisher=MTV|title=Adam Lambert Revamps 'Aftermath' for The Trevor Project|accessdate=August 21, 2011|url=http://act.mtv.com/posts/adam-lambert-revamps-aftermath-for-the-trevor-project/}}</ref><ref name="NPR">{{cite web|publisher=NPR|title=Dan Savage: For Gay Teens, Life 'Gets Better'|accessdate=August 21, 2011|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/03/23/134628750/dan-savage-for-gay-teens-life-gets-better}}</ref> The organization works with USA, The Trevor Project<ref name="MTV" /> and the [[Gay, Lesbian and Straight Education Network]].<ref name="NPR" /> The Safe Schools Coalition provides resources for teachers and students where bullying is a problem. Egale Canada works with LGBT [[Canadians|Canadian]] citizens.<ref name="City news">{{cite web|publisher=City news |title=Gay Rights Organization Egale Canada Applauds Decision On Dire Straits Song |accessdate=August 21, 2011 |url=http://www.citytv.com/toronto/citynews/entertainment/news/article/107785--gay-rights-organization-egale-canada-applauds-decision-on-dire-straits-song |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127001208/http://www.citytv.com/toronto/citynews/entertainment/news/article/107785--gay-rights-organization-egale-canada-applauds-decision-on-dire-straits-song |archivedate=January 27, 2012}}</ref> In [[Brazil]], the Gay Group of Bahia ([[Grupo Gay da Bahia]]) provides support.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ggb.org.br/ggb-ingles.html|title=Grupo Gay da Bahia - GGB|website=www.ggb.org.br}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://reporteralagoas.com.br/novo/?p=7184|title=Grupo Gay da Bahia "premia" Dilma como inimiga número 1 dos homossexuais|language=Portuguese |date=March 9, 2012|work=Repórter Alagoas |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516065359/http://reporteralagoas.com.br/novo/?p=7184 |archivedate=May 16, 2013 |accessdate=July 25, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.infosaj.com.br/ver/noticia/kit_anti_homofobia_grupo_gay_da_bahia_da_trofeu_de_inimiga_da_causa_a_presidente_dilma_rousseff.html |title=kit anti-homofobia: grupo Gay da Bahia dá troféu de "inimiga da causa" a presidente Dilma Rousseff |language=Portuguese |date=October 3, 2012 |work=TV Recôncavo |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130404121501/http://www.infosaj.com.br/ver/noticia/kit_anti_homofobia_grupo_gay_da_bahia_da_trofeu_de_inimiga_da_causa_a_presidente_dilma_rousseff.html |archivedate=April 4, 2013 |accessdate=July 25, 2017}}</ref> LGBT [[South Africa]]ns can turn to the South African Human Rights Commission.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sahrc.org.za/home/index.php?ipkContentID=1&ipkMenuID=28 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130307012102/http://www.sahrc.org.za///home/index.php?ipkContentID=1&ipkMenuID=28 |archivedate=March 7, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=August 2011}}

== Further reading ==
* Meyer, Doug (2015). Violence against Queer People: Race, Class, Gender, and the Persistence of Anti-LGBT Discrimination. Rutgers University Press. * {{cite book |title=Sexual Bullying: Gender Conflict and Pupil Culture in Secondary Schools |last=Duncan |first=Neil |year=2001 |publisher=Routledge |location=UK }} * {{cite book |title=Gender, Bullying, and Harassment: Strategies to End Sexism and Homophobia in Schools |last=Meyer |first=Elizabeth |year=2009 |publisher=Teacher’s College Press |location=USA }} * {{cite book |title=Cyberbullying and the LGBT Community |publisher=Human Rights Campaign |location=USA |url=http://www.hrc.org/issues/parenting/schools/9682.htm }} * {{cite book |title="You Have to Be Strong to Be Gay": Bullying and Educational Attainment in LGB New Zealanders |year=2008 |publisher=Journal of Gay and Lesbian Social Services |location=New Zealand}} * {{cite book |title=Traversing the Margins: Intersectionalities in the Bullying of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Youth |year=2008 |publisher=Journal of Gay and Lesbian Social Services |location=New Zealand }} * {{cite book |title=Homophobic Bullying and Same-Sex Desire in Anglo-American Schools: An Historical Perspective |year=2008 |publisher=Journal of Gay and Lesbian Social Services |location=New Zealand }} * {{cite book |title=Christianity, Social Tolerance, and Homosexuality: Gay People in Western Europe from the Beginning of the Christian Era to the Fourteenth Century |last=Boswell |first=John |year=1980 |publisher= |location= |isbn=978-0-226-06711-7 }} * {{cite journal |last1=Cuordileone |first1=K. A. |year=2000 |title='Politics in an Age of Anxiety': Cold War Political Culture and the Crisis in American Masculinity |journal=Journal of American History |volume=87 |issue=2 |pages=515–45 |doi=10.2307/2568762|jstor=2568762 }} * {{cite book |last1=D'Emilio |first1=John |editor1-first=Kathy |editor1-last=Peiss |editor2-first=Christina |editor2-last=Simmons |title=Passion and Power: Sexuality in History |year=1989 |publisher=Temple University Press |pages=226–40 |chapter=The Homosexual Menace: The Politics of Sexuality in Cold War America }} * {{cite book |title=Toward Stonewall: Homosexuality and Society in the Modern Western World |last=Edsall |first=Nicholas C. |year=2003 |publisher=U. of Virginia Press |location= |isbn=978-0-8139-2543-1 |pages=384 }} * {{cite book |title=Intimate Matters: A History of Sexuality in America, Second Edition |last1=D'Emilio |first1=John |last2=Freedman |first2=Estelle B. |year=1997 |isbn=978-0-226-14264-7 }} * {{cite book |title=Homophobia: A History |last=Fone |first=Byrne |year=2001 |isbn=978-0-312-42030-7 }} * {{cite book |title=The Gilded Age Construction of Modern American Homophobia |last=Hatheway |first=Jay |year=2003 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |isbn=978-0-312-23492-8 }} * {{cite book |title=Handbook of Lesbian and Gay Studies |chapter=Anti-Gay and Lesbian Violence and Its Discontents |last1=Jenness |first1=Valerie |last2=Richman |first2=Kimberly D. |editor1-first=Diane |editor1-last=Richardson |editor2-first=Steven |editor2-last=Seidman |year=2002 |pages=403+}} * {{cite book |title=Making Hate a Crime: From Social Movement to Law Enforcement |last1=Jenness |first1=Valerie |last2=Grattet |first2=Ryken |year=2001 |isbn=978-0-87154-409-4}} * {{cite book |title=The Lavender Scare: The Cold War Persecution of Gays and Lesbians in the Federal Government |last=Johnson |first=David K. |year=2004 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |isbn=978-0-226-40190-4}} * {{cite book |title=Homophobia: Description, Development, and Dynamics of Gay Bashing |last=Kantor |first=Martin |year=1998 |isbn=978-0-275-95530-4}} * {{cite book |title=Departing from Deviance: A History of Homosexual Rights and Emancipatory Science in America |last=Minton |first=Henry L. |year=2002 |publisher=U. of Chicago Press |isbn=978-0-226-53044-4|pages=344 }} * {{cite journal | last1 = Padva | first1 = Gilad | year = 2007 | title = Media and Popular Culture Representations of LGBT Bullying | url = | journal = Journal of Gay and Lesbian Social Services | volume = 19 | issue = 3–4| pages = 105–118 | doi=10.1080/10538720802161615}} * {{cite book |title=The Velvet Rage, Overcoming the Pain of Growing Up Gay in a Straight Man's World |last=Downs |first=Alan |year=2005 |publisher=Da Capo Press}} * {{cite book |title="Dude, You're a Fag", Masculinity and Sexuality in High School |last=Pascoe |first=CJ |year=2007 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0520271487}} * {{cite book |title=Bullying at School, What We Know and What We Can Do |last=Olweus |first=Dan |year=1993 |publisher=Blackwell |isbn=978-0631192398}}

revision.comment: CE
revision.text:
'''Gomocup''' is a worldwide tournament of artificial intelligences (AI) playing [[Gomoku]] and [[Renju]]. The tournament has been played since 2000 and takes place every year.{{cite web|title=The Gomoku AI programming tournament|url=http://gomocup.org/home/|website=Gomocup|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604205643/http://gomocup.org/home/|archivedate=2016-06-04|df=}} As of 2016,{{cite news|title=Gomocup 2016, the 17th tournament (April the 22nd-24th, 2016)|url=http://gomocup.org/results/gomocup-result-2016/}} it is the most famous and largest Gomoku AI tournament in the world, with around 40 participants from about 10 countries. == Rules == Gomocup has been played in the freestyle Gomoku rule with the board size of 20 since it was started in 2000.{{Cite web|url=http://gomocup.org/detail-information/|title=Detailed Information|last=|first=|date=|website=Gomocup|publisher=|access-date=}} In 2009, the standard Gomoku rule was added into Gomocup as a tournament, in which the board size is 15 and more than five in a row is not considered to be a win.{{Cite web|url=http://gomocup.org/results/gomocup-result-2009/|title=Gomocup 2009, the 10th tournament (April the 4th, 2009)|last=|first=|date=|website=Gomocup|publisher=|access-date=}} In 2016, the Renju rule was also added into Gomocup, with a board size of 15 and forbidden moves for black.{{Cite web|url=http://gomocup.org/gomocup-2016-announcement/|title=Gomocup 2016 Announcement|last=|first=|date=|website=Gomocup|publisher=|access-date=}} In particular, since there are a large number of participants in the freestyle Gomoku tournament, the freestyle Gomoku tournament is divided into several leagues, and the fast game tournament is introduced.{{Cite web|url=http://gomocup.org/results/gomocup-result-2005/|title=Gomocup 2005, the 6th tournament (April the 16th, 2005)|last=|first=|date=|website=Gomocup|publisher=|access-date=}} To get rid of the fact that there is a winning strategy for the player who plays first in Gomoku,{{Cite web|url=http://www.renju.nu/wp-content/uploads/sites/46/2016/09/Go-Moku.pdf|title=Go-Moku and Threat Space Search}} balanced openings have been prepared by Gomoku experts since 2006.{{Cite web|url=http://gomocup.org/results/gomocup-result-2006/|title=Gomocup 2006, the 7th tournament (April the 28th, 2006)|last=|first=|date=|website=Gomocup|publisher=|access-date=}} Games would be started from these balanced openings, and neither side would have a big advantage from the very beginning. == AI vs. Human Tournament == There were two AI vs. Human tournaments held in the Czech Republic in 2006 and 2011. In 2006, the top 3 programs in Gomocup had a tournament with 3 of the top 10 players in Piškvorky online. There were 2 games between each pair of AI and human players. The result was one win, one draw and one loss for AIs, and the total score was 3:3.{{Cite web|url=http://gomocup.org/results/ai-human-2006/|title=The 1st tournament AI vs. Human (November the 11th, 2006)|last=|first=|date=|website=Gomocup|publisher=|access-date=2016-06-02}} In 2011, the tournament was between the top 4 programs in Gomocup and 4 players at the top of the Czech Gomoku rating list. Similar to the 1st tournament, there were 2 games between each pair of AI. This time there were 3 draws and 1 win for AIs, and the total score was 5:3.{{Cite web|url=http://www.piskvorky.cz/clanky/zajimavosti-ze-sveta-piskvorek-a-renju/ai-vs-clovek-2011-2/|title=AI vs. Člověk 2011 {{!}} Česká federace piškvorek a renju|website=www.piskvorky.cz|access-date=2016-06-02}} == Elo Rating == The [[Elo rating system]] for Gomocup was built in 2016 and calculated with all the historical tournament results ever since.{{Cite web|url=http://gomocup.org/elo-ratings/|title=Elo Ratings|last=|first=|date=|website=Gomocup|publisher=|access-date=}} The rating is calculated with the open-source tool BayesElo,{{Cite web|url=http://www.remi-coulom.fr/Bayesian-Elo/|title=Bayesian Elo Rating|last=Coulom|first=Rémi|website=www.remi-coulom.fr|access-date=2016-06-02}} with a few parameters modified to get adapted to the Gomoku game. There is a rating list for each game rule. The Elo ratings are updated every year after the Gomocup tournament finishes. {| |- style="vertical-align: top;" | {| class="wikitable" |+ Elo Ratings for Freestyle Gomoku |- ! Rank !! AI !! revision.comment: /* T-cell functional dysregulation as a biomarker for immunosenescence */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Archives of dermatology → Archives of Dermatology using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Immunosenescence''' refers to the gradual deterioration of the [[immune system]] brought on by [[Ageing|natural age advancement]]. It involves both the host’s capacity to respond to infections and the development of long-term immune memory, especially by [[vaccination]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Local and systemic immune response in nursing-home elderly following intranasal or intramuscular immunization with inactivated influenza vaccine|journal=Vaccine|year=2003|first=M|last=Muszkat|author2=E. Greenbaum |author3=A. Ben-Yehuda |author4=M. Oster |author5=E. Yeu'l |author6=S. Heimann |author7=R. Levy |author8=G. Friedman |author9=Z. Zakay-Rones |volume=21|issue=11–12|pages=1180–1186|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1016/S0264-410X(02)00481-4|pmid=12559796 }}</ref> This age-associated [[immune deficiency]] is ubiquitous and found in both long- and short-living species as a function of their age relative to life expectancy rather than chronological time.<ref name="Ginaldi2001">{{cite journal|title=Immunosenescence and infectious diseases|journal=Microbes and Infection|year=2001|first=L.|last=Ginaldi |author2=M.F. Loreto |author3=M.P. Corsi |author4=M. Modesti |author5=M. de Martinis |volume=3|issue=10|pages=851–857 |id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1016/S1286-4579(01)01443-5|pmid=11580980 }}</ref> It is considered a major contributory factor to the increased frequency of morbidity and mortality among the elderly.
Immunosenescence is not a random deteriorative phenomenon, rather it appears to inversely repeat an evolutionary pattern and most of the parameters affected by immunosenescence appear to be under genetic control.<ref name="Franceschi1999">{{cite journal|title=Biomarkers of immunosenescence within an evolutionary perspective: the challenge of heterogeneity and the role of antigenic load|journal=Experimental Gerontology|year=1999|first=C.|last=Franceschi |author2=S. Valensin |author3=F. Fagnoni |author4=C. Barbi |author5=M. Bonafe|volume=34|issue=8|pages=911–921|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1016/S0531-5565(99)00068-6 }}</ref> Immunosenescence can also be sometimes envisaged as the result of the continuous challenge of the unavoidable exposure to a variety of [[antigens]] such as [[viruses]] and [[bacteria]].<ref name="Franceschi2000">{{cite journal|title=Human immunosenescence: the prevailing of innate immunity, the failing of clonotypic immunity, and the filling of immunological space|journal=Vaccine|year=2000|first=C.|last=Franceschi |author2=M. Bonafè |author3=S. Valensin|volume=18|issue=16|pages=1717–1720|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1016/S0264-410X(99)00513-7|pmid=10689155 }}</ref>
== Overview of the age-associated decline in immune function == Immunosenescence is a multifactorial condition leading to many pathologically significant health problems in the aged population. Some of the age-dependent biological changes that contribute to the onset of immunosenescence are listed below: * [[Hematopoietic stem cells]] (HSC), which provide the regulated lifelong supply of [[leukocyte]] progenitors that are in turn able to differentiate into a diversity of specialised immune cells (including [[lymphocytes]], [[Antigen-presenting cell|antigen-presenting]] [[dendritic cells]] and [[phagocytes]]) diminish in their self-renewal capacity. This is due to the accumulation of [[Oxidative stress|oxidative damage]] to [[DNA]] by aging and cellular metabolic activity<ref> High frequency electromagnetic waves such as gamma and xrays can penetrate and damage DNA.
{{cite journal|title=Regulation of oxidative stress by ATM is required for self-renewal of haematopoietic stem cells|journal=Nature|year=2004|first=K|last=Ito |author2=A. Hirao |author3=F. Arai |author4=S. Matsuoka |author5=K. Takubo |author6=I. Hamaguchi |author7=K. Nomiyama |author8=K. Hosokawa |author9=K. Sakurada |author10=N. Nakagata |author11=Y. Ikeda |author12=T. W. Mak |author13=T. Suda |volume=431|issue=7011|pages=997–1002 |id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1038/nature02989|pmid=15496926 }}</ref> and the shortening of telomeric terminals of chromosomes. * There is a notable decline in the total number of [[phagocytes]] in aged hosts, coupled with an intrinsic reduction of their [[Bactericide|bactericidal]] activity.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Neutrophil ageing and immunesenescence|journal=Mech Ageing Dev|year=2001|first=J.M.|last=Lord|author2=S. Butcher |author3=V. Killampali |author4=D. Lascelles |author5=M. Salmon |volume=122|issue=14|pages=1521–1535|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1016/S0047-6374(01)00285-8|pmid=11511394 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Immunosenescence and macrophage functional plasticity: dysregulation of macrophage function by age-associated microenvironmental changes|journal=Immunol Rev|year=2005|first=R.D.|last=Strout|author2=J. Suttles|volume=205|issue=|pages=60–71|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1111/j.0105-2896.2005.00260.x|pmid=15882345|pmc=1201508 }}</ref> * The cytotoxicity of [[Natural killer cell|Natural Killer]] (NK) cells and the antigen-presenting function of dendritic cells is known to diminish with old age.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Decreased natural killer cell activity is associated with atherosclerosis in elderly humans|journal=Exp Gerontol|year=2001|first=H.|last=Bruunsgaard |author2=A. N. Pedersen |author3=M. Schroll |author4=P. Skinhoj |author5=B. K. Pedersen|volume=37|issue=1|pages=127–136|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1016/S0531-5565(01)00162-0|pmid=11738153 }}</ref><ref name="Mocchegiani2004">{{cite journal|title=NK and NKT cell functions in immunosenescence|journal=Aging Cell|year=2004|first=E|last=Mocchegiani|author2=M. Malavolta|volume=3|issue=4|pages=177–184|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1111/j.1474-9728.2004.00107.x|pmid=15268751 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=The frail elderly: role of dendritic cells in the susceptibility of infection|journal=Mech Ageing Dev|year=2002|first=K.|last=Uyemura|author2=S. C. Castle |author3=T. Makinodan |volume=123|issue=8|pages=955–962|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1016/S0047-6374(02)00033-7|pmid=12044944 }}</ref> The age-associated impairment of dendritic [[Antigen-presenting cell|Antigen Presenting Cells]] (APCs) has profound implications as this translates into a deficiency in [[cell-mediated immunity]] and thus, the inability for effector [[T-lymphocytes]] to modulate an [[adaptive immune response]] (see below). * A decline in [[humoral immunity]] caused by a reduction in the population of [[antibody]] producing [[B-cells]] along with a smaller [[immunoglobulin]] diversity and [[Dissociation constant#Protein-ligand binding|affinity]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gibson|first1=KL|last2=Wu|first2=Y-C|last3=Barnett|first3=Y|last4=Duggan|first4=O|last5=Vaughan|first5=R|last6=Kondeatis|first6=E|last7=Nilsson|first7=BO|last8=Wikby|first8=A|last9=Kipling|first9=D|last10=Dunn-Walters|first10=DK|title=B cell diversity decreases in old age and is correlated with poor health status.|journal=Ageing Cell|date=2009|volume=8|pages=18–25|doi=10.1111/j.1474-9726.2008.00443.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Enhanced differentiation of splenic plasma cells but diminished long-lived high-affinity bone marrow plasma cells in aged mice|journal=J Immunol|year=2003|first=S.|last=Han|author2=K. Yang |author3=Z. Ozen |author4=W. Peng |author5=E. Marinova |author6=G. Kelsoe |author7=B. Zheng |volume=170|issue=3|pages=1267–1273|id= |url=|accessdate=|pmid=12538685 |doi=10.4049/jimmunol.170.3.1267}}</ref>
As age advances, there is decline in both the production of new naive [[lymphocytes]] and the functional competence of memory cell populations. This has been implicated in the increasing frequency and severity of diseases such as [[cancer]], chronic inflammatory disorders, [[breakthrough infection]]s and [[autoimmunity]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Immunosenescence: deficits in adaptive immunity in elderly|journal=Tissue Antigens|year=2007|first=F.T.|last=Hakim|author2=R.E. Gress|volume=70|issue=3|pages=179–189|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1111/j.1399-0039.2007.00891.x|pmid=17661905 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Haq|first=Kamran|last2=McElhaney|first2=Janet E|title=Immunosenescence: influenza vaccination and the elderly|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0952791514000569|journal=Current Opinion in Immunology|volume=29|pages=38–42|doi=10.1016/j.coi.2014.03.008}}</ref> A problem of infections in the elderly is that they frequently present with non-specific signs and symptoms, and clues of focal infection are often absent or obscured by underlying chronic conditions.<ref name="Ginaldi2001" /> Ultimately, this provides problems in diagnosis and subsequently, treatment.
In addition to changes in immune responses, the beneficial effects of [[inflammation]] devoted to the neutralisation of dangerous and harmful agents early in life and in adulthood become detrimental late in life in a period largely not foreseen by evolution, according to the antagonistic [[pleiotropy]] theory of aging.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.2000.tb06651.x|title=Inflamm-aging: An Evolutionary Perspective on Immunosenescence|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|year=2000|first=C.|last=Franceschi |author2=M. Bonafe |author3=S. Valensin |author4=F. Olivieri |author5=M. de Luca |author6=E. Ottaviani |author7=G. de Benedictis |volume=908|issue=|pages=244–254|id= |url=|accessdate=|pmid=10911963 }}</ref> It should be further noted that changes in the lymphoid compartment is not solely responsible for the malfunctioning of the [[immune system]] in the elderly. Although myeloid cell production does not seem to decline with age, [[macrophages]] become dysregulated as a consequence of environmental changes.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Immunosenescence: a problem of lymphopoiesis, homeostasis, microenvironment, and signaling|journal=Immunological reviews|year=2005|first=J.|last=Cambier|volume=205|issue=|pages=5–6|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1111/j.0105-2896.2005.00276.x|pmid=15882340 }}</ref>
== T-cell functional dysregulation as a biomarker for immunosenescence == The functional capacity of [[T-cells]] is most influenced by the effects of aging. In fact, age-related alterations are evident in all stages of T-cell development, making them a significant factor in the development of immunosenescence.<ref>{{cite journal|title=T cell function in the aged: Lessons learned from animal models|journal=Clinical and Applied Immunology Reviews|year=2006|first=P.-J|last=Linton|author2=J. Lustgarten |author3=M. Thoman |volume=6|issue=2|pages=73–97|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1016/j.cair.2006.06.001 }}</ref> After birth, the decline of T-cell function begins with the progressive [[involution (medicine)|involution]] of the [[thymus]], which is the organ essential for T-cell maturation following the migration of precursor cells from the bone marrow. This age-associated decrease of thymic [[Epithelium|epithelial]] volume results in a reduction/exhaustion on the number of [[thymocytes]] (i.e. pre-mature T-cells), thus reducing output of peripheral naïve T-cells.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Thymic involution in aging|journal=J Clin Immunol|year=2000|first=R.|last=Aspinall|author2=D. Andrew|volume=20|issue=4|pages=250–256|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1023/A:1006611518223|pmid=10939712 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Reduction in the developmental potential of intrathymic T cell progenitors with age|journal=J Immunol|year=2004|first=H.|last=Min|author2=E. Montecino-Rodriguez |author3=K. Dorshkind |volume=173|issue=1|pages=245–250|id= |url=|accessdate=|pmid=15210781 |doi=10.4049/jimmunol.173.1.245}}</ref> Once matured and circulating throughout the peripheral system, T-cells still undergo deleterious age-dependent changes. Together with the age-related thymic involution, and the consequent age-related decrease of thymic output of new T cells, this situation leaves the body practically devoid of virgin T cells, which makes the body more prone to a variety of infectious and non-infectious diseases.<ref name="Franceschi2000" /> T-cell components associated with immunosenescence include: * reduction in the [[CD4+/CD8+ ratio]]<ref name="pmid16456027">{{cite journal | vauthors=Hadrup SR, Strindhall J, Køllgaard T, Seremet T, Johansson B, Pawelec G, thor Straten P, Wikby A | title=Longitudinal studies of clonally expanded CD8 T cells reveal a repertoire shrinkage predicting mortality and an increased number of dysfunctional cytomegalovirus-specific T cells in the very elderly | journal= [[Journal of Immunology]] | volume=176 | issue=4 | pages=2645–2653 | year=2006 | url = http://www.jimmunol.org/content/176/4/2645.long |doi = 10.4049/jimmunol.176.4.2645 | pmid=16456027}}</ref> * impaired development of CD4+ [[Follicular B Helper T cells|T follicular helper cells]], which are specialized in facilitating peripheral [[B cell]] maturation, and the generation of antibody-producing [[plasma cell]]s and [[memory B cell]]s<ref>{{cite journal|title=The aged microenvironment contributes to the age-related functional defects of CD4 T cells in mice|journal=Aging Cell|year=2012|vauthors=Lefebvre JS, Maue AC, Eaton SM, Lanthier PA, Tighe M, Haynes L |volume=11|issue=5|pages=732–40|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1111/j.1474-9726.2012.00836.x|pmid=22607653|pmc=3444657}}</ref> * deregulation of intracellular [[signal transduction]] capabilities<ref>{{cite journal|title=Age-related impairment of p56lck and ZAP-70 activities in human T lymphocytes activated through the TcR/CD3 complex|journal=Exp Gerontol|year=1999|first=T., Jr.|last=Fulop|author2=D. Gagne |author3=A. C. Goulet |author4=S. Desgeorges |author5=G. Lacombe |author6=M. Arcand |author7=G. Dupuis |volume=34|issue=2|pages=197–216|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1016/S0531-5565(98)00061-8|pmid=10363787 }}</ref> * diminished capacity to produce effector [[lymphokines]]<ref name="Murciano2006">{{cite journal|title=Impaired immune response to Candida albicans in aged mice|journal=J Med Microbiol|year=2006|first=C.|last=Murciano|author2=E. Villamon |author3=A. Yanez |author4=J. E. O'Connor |author5=D. Gozalbo |author6=M. L. Gil |volume=55|issue=Pt 12|pages=1649–1656|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1099/jmm.0.46740-0|pmid=17108267 }}</ref><ref name="Voehringer2002">{{cite journal|title=Lack of proliferative capacity of human effector and memory T cells expressing killer cell lectinlike receptor G1 (KLRG1)|journal=Blood|year=2002|first=D.|last=Voehringer|author2=M. Koschella |author3=H. Pircher |volume=100|issue=10|pages=3698–3702|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1182/blood-2002-02-0657|pmid=12393723 }}</ref><ref name="Ouyang2003">{{cite journal|title=Age-associated accumulation of CMV-specific CD8+ T cells expressing the inhibitory killer cell lectin-like receptor G1 (KLRG1)|journal=Exp Gerontol|year=2003|first=Q.|last=Ouyang|author2=W. M. Wagner |author3=D. Voehringer |author4=A. Wikby |author5=T. Klatt |author6=S. Walter |author7=C. A. Muller |author8=H. Pircher |author9=G. Pawelec |volume=38|issue=8|pages=911–920|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1016/S0531-5565(03)00134-7|pmid=12915213 }}</ref> * shrinkage of antigen-recognition repertoire of [[T-cell receptor]] (TcR) diversity<ref name="Naylor2005">{{cite journal|title=The influence of age on T cell generation and TCR diversity|journal=J Immunol|year=2005|first=K.|last=Naylor|author2=G. Li |author3=A. N. Vallejo |author4=W. W. Lee |author5=K. Koetz |author6=E. Bryl |author7=J. Witkowski |author8=J. Fulbright |author9=C. M. Weyand |author10=J. J. Goronzy |volume=174|issue=11|pages=7446–7452|id= |url=|accessdate=|pmid=15905594 |doi=10.4049/jimmunol.174.11.7446}}</ref><ref name="Weng2006">{{cite journal|title=Aging of the Immune System: How Much Can the Adaptive Immune System Adapt?|journal=Immunity|year=2006|first=N. P. |last=Weng|volume=24|issue=5|pages=495–499|id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1016/j.immuni.2006.05.001|pmid=16713964|pmc=2266981 }}</ref> * cytotoxic activity of [[Natural Killer T cell|Natural Killer T-cells]] (NKTs) decreases<ref name="Mocchegiani2004" /> * impaired proliferation in response to antigenic stimulation<ref name="Murciano2006" /><ref name="Voehringer2002" /><ref name="Naylor2005" /><ref name="Weng2006" /> * the accumulation and the clonal expansion of memory and effector T-cells<ref name="Franceschi1999" /><ref name="Voehringer2002" /> * hampered immune defences against [[virus|viral pathogens]], especially by [[Cytotoxic T cell|cytotoxic CD8+ T cells]]<ref name="Ouyang2003" /> * changes in [[cytokine]] profile e.g. increased pro-inflammatory cytokines ''milieu'' present in the elderly<ref>{{cite journal|title=Aging and the skin immune system|journal=Archives of Dermatology|year=1997|first=C.|last=Suderkotter|author2=H. Kalden|volume=133|issue=10|pages=1256–1262 |id= |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1001/archderm.133.10.1256|pmid=9382564 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{Primary sources|date=June 2017}} {{Notability|date=June 2017}}}}{{Infobox software | title = inspectIT | name = inspectIT | logo = File:InspectIT APM Logo.svg | screenshot = File:Screenshot of inspectIT.png | caption = Screenshot of inspectIT 1.7.7 | developer = NovaTec Consulting GmbH, inspectIT Community | latest release version = 1.7.11.94 <ref>https://github.com/inspectIT/inspectIT/releases/tag/1.7.11.94</ref> | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2017|05|19|df=yes|paren=yes}} | latest preview version = 1.8.4.98 <ref>https://github.com/inspectIT/inspectIT/releases/tag/1.8.4.98</ref> | latest preview date = {{Start date and age|2017|09|15|df=yes|paren=yes}} | repo = https://github.com/inspectIT/inspectIT | programming language = [[Java (programming language)|Java]] | operating system = Cross-platform | genre = application performance management | license = Apache License, Version 2.0 <ref>https://github.com/inspectIT/inspectIT/blob/master/license/LICENSE.txt</ref> | website = [http://inspectit.rocks Website] }} '''inspectIT''' is an [[Open-source software|open-source]] [[application performance management]] (APM) tool, which enables the diagnosis, analysis and monitoring of [[Java (programming language)|Java]] applications. inspectIT is developed by NovaTec Consulting GmbH, an IT consulting company from [[Stuttgart]] ([[Germany]]), but it has been made open-source in August 2015.
== Functionality == inspectIT follows a "user-transaction-centered” approach whereby the focus is on the analysis of concrete user requests. For each request against a system which is supervised by inspectIT, a detailed [[Call graph|call tree]], named ''invocation sequence'', is constructed. The ''invocation sequences'' contain the exact execution times of all invocations of instrumented methods. Using this information, user requests can be analyzed and root causes of potential problems can be discovered. Also included in the ''invocation sequences'' are all requests against [[database]]s which can be used to detect and solve problems in the database access layer or certain queries.
Since version 1.8.1, inspectIT offers functionality for [[real user monitoring]] that records user interaction with, for example, a website or web-based application.
== Architecture == The architecture of inspectIT consists of three main components: * '''inspectIT Agent''' - it is integrated into the system which should be supervised, collects diagnostic information of the integrated measuring points and sends the gathered data to the central ''inspectIT Server''. The agent is designed to introduce as little as possible [[Overhead (computing)|overhead]] into the target system, in terms of CPU and memory usage. * '''inspectIT Server''' (also called ''centralized measurement repository'' (CMR)) - it receives, processes and stores the diagnostic information sent by the inspectIT agents and provides it to the inspectIT user interface. * '''inspectIT User Interface''' - it is an [[Eclipse (software)#Rich Client Platform|Eclipse RPC]] based application and enables the analysis of the diagnostic information provided by the ''inspectIT Server''.
== Functioning == During the Java class loading process of the [[Java virtual machine|JVM]], a Java-based agent<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://docs.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/instrument/package-summary.html|title=java.lang.instrument (Java 2 Platform SE 5.0)|website=docs.oracle.com|access-date=2017-04-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/index.html?java/lang/instrument/package-summary.html|title=Java Platform SE 6|website=docs.oracle.com|access-date=2017-04-26}}</ref> is integrated into the class loading process which is able to intercept and modify the [[Java bytecode|Java Bytecode]] of loaded [[Java class file|classes]]. Contrary to profilers, inspectIT injects measurement points only at specific locations to keep the [[Overhead (computing)|overhead]] of the measurements at a minimum. Using this approach, it allows the user to transparently inject measurement points into an application without adapting its [[source code]].
== History and Naming == The development of inspectIT started in the year 2005 under the name NovaSpy as [[Proprietary software|closed source software]]. It was renamed into inspectIT in 2008 and the first major release (version 1.0) has been released in March 2010. Since then, new versions have been released on a regular basis.
=== Open Source === On August 14, 2015, inspectIT has been made available as [[open-source software]] under the [[Apache License|Apache License, Version 2.0]] (ALv2).
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == <!-- Use the format: * [http://www.example.com/ example.com] --> * [http://www.inspectit.rocks/ Official website] * [https://inspectit-performance.atlassian.net/wiki Documentation] * [http://www.novatec-gmbh.de Website of founding developer]

Neuroinformatics Coordinating Facility logotype, abbreviation-only style. | caption = | map = <!-- map image --> | map_size = <!-- defaults to 250px --> | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = <!-- second map image, if required --> | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = INCF | motto = Advancing global collaborative brain research.<ref name=INCF-about>{{cite web |title=About us |website=INCF |url=https://www.incf.org/about-us |access-date=19 September 2017 }}</ref> | predecessor = | merged = <!-- Any other organizations with which the organization was merged --> | successor = | formation = {{start date and age|2005}}<ref name=INCF-history>{{cite web |title=History |website=INCF |url=https://www.incf.org/about-us/history |access-date=19 September 2017 }}</ref> |
